title: 5 Key Differences: Smart Locks vs. Traditional Locks in Durbanville üîê
excerpt: Should you upgrade to a smart lock? We compare the security, convenience, and reliability of smart locks vs. traditional locks for Cape Town homes.
author: Global Security Team
metaTitle: Smart Locks vs Traditional Locks in Cape Town
metaDescription: Should you upgrade to a smart lock? We compare the security, convenience, and reliability of smart locks vs. traditional locks for Cape Town homes.

content.text: Fumbling for your keys in the dark during Stage 6 load shedding is incredibly frustrating. Even worse, handing out spare keys to contractors or domestic staff means you never truly know who has access to your property.

Relying solely on old-school keys can leave you vulnerable to lost, stolen, or secretly copied keys. If you ignore who is entering your property, you drastically increase your risk of a break-in. In this article, we explain exactly how to choose between smart locks and traditional deadbolts to best protect your home.

The short answer? Smart locks win hands-down for convenience, remote access, and tracking exactly who enters your home. However, high-grade traditional locks still hold the crown for raw physical resistance against brute-force attacks.
1. Ultimate Convenience and Keyless Entry
In our experience, the biggest reason clients switch to smart locks is convenience. You never have to worry about locking yourself out or carrying a bulky set of keys while going for a run.

Most modern smart locks allow you to unlock your door via fingerprint, PIN code, a smartphone app, or even a specialized key tag. If you want to integrate this with larger Access Control Solutions, smart locks are the perfect starting point for seamless entry.
2. Tracking Access and Remote Control
A traditional lock can't tell you who opened the door or at what time. Smart technology changes that completely.

If you are at work in the CBD, you can generate a temporary PIN code for a plumber or electrician and delete it the moment they leave. You also receive push notifications on your phone when your kids get home from school, giving you absolute peace of mind.

content.alt: Technician installing a modern smart lock on a residential door in Cape Town.

content.text: 3. Surviving Load Shedding
One of the most common questions we get is, "Will I be locked out during a power outage?" It's a valid concern given our local power grid.

Fortunately, most residential smart locks run on standard AA batteries, meaning they operate completely independently of your home's main power supply. However, if your lock relies heavily on Wi-Fi for remote unlocking, your router will need a backup power source. For more tips on keeping your systems online, check out our Load Shedding Security Guide.

Pro Tip: Always carry the physical backup key (which comes with almost all smart locks) in your car or bag. If the smart lock batteries die unexpectedly, you can still open the door the traditional way!
4. Physical Strength against Intruders

While smart locks are brilliant for access management, traditional heavy-duty deadbolts are incredibly tough. Criminals in areas around the Northern Suburbs often try to use brute force, crowbars, or heavy tools to bypass front doors.

During a recent consultation for a family looking for Durbanville Security Services, we found that a high-grade traditional deadbolt paired with a sturdy security gate offered the most cost-effective physical barrier. Smart locks are secure, but you must ensure the actual deadbolt mechanism it controls is rated for high security.

content.alt: Comparison of a traditional deadbolt and a digital smart lock keypad.

content.text: 5. Making the Right Choice for Your Property
We often find that a hybrid approach works best for Cape Town homes. You don't have to choose just one.

Use a high-quality smart lock on your main entrance door for daily convenience and access tracking. Then, use traditional, high-security deadbolts on secondary doors or security gates where convenience is less of a daily priority, but absolute physical strength is required.
Conclusion & Pitch

Deciding between smart locks and traditional locks comes down to balancing daily convenience with raw physical security. Smart locks offer incredible control over who enters your property, while traditional locks remain a steadfast physical barrier.

title: 3 Ways to Stop Gate Remote Jamming in Cape Town üö´
excerpt: Remote jamming is a rising threat in Cape Town. Learn how criminals block your gate signal, how to prevent it, and keep your property secure.
author: Global Security Team

content.text: The Pain: You press your gate remote, the motor beeps, and you drive away to work. But what if the gate never actually closed behind you?

The Agitation: Criminals are increasingly using remote jammers to gain silent, unforced entry into properties across the Western Cape. If your gate is left wide open, your home, family, and vehicles are completely exposed to intruders.
The Promise: In this article, we explain exactly how criminals block your gate's signal and how to fix this vulnerability immediately.

The Short Answer: Criminals use illegal handheld devices to flood the 433MHz radio frequency, blocking your remote‚Äôs signal so your gate won't close. To prevent this, you must physically watch the gate close, upgrade to a smart gate motor with push notifications, or install a dedicated signal jamming detector.
How Gate Remote Jamming Actually Works

Criminals often wait in unmarked vehicles near your driveway. They carry a simple electronic jamming device that broadcasts a powerful, continuous radio signal. Most standard remotes operate on the open 433MHz frequency band.

When you press your remote to close the gate, their jamming device drowns out your remote's signal. It acts exactly like a blasting siren covering up a whisper. Your gate motor simply does not receive the command to close.

You drive away assuming the property is secure, but the gate remains wide open. Criminals then have unrestricted access to walk right in, making it one of the most common methods seen in our latest crime trends data.

content.alt: Driver pressing a gate remote in Cape Town to close an automated driveway gate.

content.text: How to Spot a Jamming Attempt

Being able to recognize a jamming attack as it happens is your first line of defense. Unlike a physical break-in, jamming leaves no damage, no broken locks, and no forced entry. It relies entirely on stealth and your own distraction.

Usually, the first sign is that your gate or garage simply becomes unresponsive. You might assume the battery in your remote is dead, or that the motor is acting up. In reality, a criminal sitting nearby is actively holding down the button on their jamming device.

Another major red flag is the presence of unfamiliar, occupied vehicles parked unusually close to your driveway. Criminals need to be within a certain range for their jammers to successfully block your signal. If you notice a suspicious car lingering while your remote magically stops working, treat it as a live security threat.
1. The "Wait and Watch" Rule
In our experience, the most effective immediate defense costs absolutely nothing. You simply need to change your daily driving habits. Never press the button and immediately drive down the street.

Always wait in your driveway or pause in the road until the gate has fully closed and the latch engages. Criminals rely on you being distracted or in a rush. If they see you waiting, they will usually abandon the attempt.

On a recent installation in Durbanville, a client reviewed their CCTV and saw how a criminal casually walked in just seconds after the owner drove off. Staying vigilant eliminates this window of opportunity completely.

Safety Note: If you are pressing your remote and the gate refuses to respond while a suspicious vehicle is parked nearby, do not get out of your car. Drive away to a safe, public location and contact your local armed response or neighborhood watch immediately.
2. Upgrade Your Gate and Garage Automation

Older systems are incredibly vulnerable to both signal cloning and jamming attacks. Upgrading your gate and garage automation is a critical step in securing your perimeter. Modern systems, like the Centurion D5 SMART, offer advanced features that older motors lack.

These newer systems use rolling-code technology which makes cloning impossible. More importantly, they connect directly to your smartphone. If your gate is left open for longer than a few minutes, the app will send an immediate push notification to your phone.

We also highly recommend integrating hardwired safety beams and keypads where possible. Because these components are physically wired to the control board, they cannot be blocked by wireless radio jammers.

content.alt: Modern Centurion D5 SMART gate motor with anti-theft bracket installed in Cape Town.

content.text: 3. Install Anti-Jamming Detectors

If you live in a high-risk area, installing a dedicated signal jamming detector is an excellent proactive measure. These clever devices constantly monitor the radio frequencies around your driveway and property.

If the detector picks up a continuous, suspicious transmission trying to block signals in the 433MHz or 868MHz bands, it takes immediate action. The system can be wired to trigger your main house alarm, turn on floodlights, or notify your security company.

These units act as an invisible shield for your property's wireless communications. They ensure that even if a criminal tries to use a jammer, you and your security team are alerted before they ever step foot onto your driveway.
Conclusion & Pitch
Gate remote jamming is a serious but entirely preventable threat. By staying vigilant, watching your gate close, and utilizing modern smart motor technology, you can stop criminals in their tracks.

content.text: The Pain: If you‚Äôre still handing out plastic proximity cards to your staff, you aren‚Äôt just managing access‚Äîyou‚Äôre managing a massive security loophole.

The Agitation: In our years of servicing sites from Durbanville to Paarl, we‚Äôve seen it all: cards left in Uber rides, "buddy clocking" where one staff member taps in for three late colleagues, and disgruntled ex-employees keeping cards that weren't deactivated fast enough.

The Promise: In this article, we‚Äôll show you why biometrics are the only way to ensure 100% accountability. The bottom line? You can‚Äôt lend someone your thumbprint. Biometrics bridge the gap between "someone has a key" and "the right person is in the building."
1. Killing the "Buddy Clocking" Culture
In the industrial hubs of Paarl and Kuils River, time fraud is a silent profit killer. When we audit systems, we often find 10‚Äì15% discrepancies in payroll because of card swapping.

By switching to staff time and attendance via fingerprint or facial recognition, you ensure your payroll is honest. At GSS, we integrate these readers directly into your management software so you can see exactly who is on-site in real-time.
2. The "Sea Air" Factor: Durability Matters

Cape Town‚Äôs environment is brutal on electronics. In areas like Blouberg and Milnerton, we‚Äôve seen standard card readers fail within months due to salt-air corrosion of the internal contact points.

We recommend IP65-rated biometric terminals. Because these units are often sealed for outdoor use, they handle the Western Cape‚Äôs humidity and dust far better than old-school magnetic stripe or "swipe" systems.

Pro Tip: If your staff work with oils or heavy machinery (common in Industrial Security settings), we suggest Facial Recognition over fingerprints. It‚Äôs touchless, lightning-fast, and works even if hands are dirty or covered in grease.

content.alt: GSS technician installing a Hikvision facial recognition terminal for a Cape Town business.

content.text: 3. Real-Time Revocation (No More "Lost" Keys)

When a staff member leaves your company in a place like Stellenbosch, you don't want to be chasing them for a physical key or card. With Biometric Access Control, you simply delete their profile from the database. Access is revoked instantly across every door in the building. No locks to change, no cards to re-order.
4. Precision for High-Risk Zones

In Commercial Security, not all doors are equal. Your front gate is one thing, but your server room or stock floor is another. We often set up "Multi-Factor Authentication" for our clients: a card plus a fingerprint for sensitive areas. This ensures that even if a card is stolen, the thief still can't get to the "crown jewels" of your business.

title: Wired vs. Wireless Alarms: What is Best for Cape Town Homes? üè†
excerpt: Unsure which alarm system fits your home? We compare Paradox vs. Ajax, installation costs, and reliability for Cape Town properties.
author: Global Security Team

content.text: The Pain: You are finally ready to install a security system, or perhaps upgrade an old dinosaur of a keypad that‚Äôs been beeping incessantly. But you‚Äôre immediately hit with the biggest question in the industry: "Should I go wired or wireless?"

The Agitation: It is a valid concern. Make the wrong choice, and you could end up with unsightly trunking running along your beautiful cornices, or conversely, a wireless system that drops signal every time your neighbour turns on their microwave. In the security game, reliability is everything‚Äîif your alarm doesn't trigger when it matters, the investment was wasted.

The Promise: In this article, we draw on our years of experience installing systems across the Western Cape to give you an unbiased comparison. We break down the differences between leading brands like Paradox and Ajax to help you decide.

The Short Answer: If you are building a new home or renovating, wired is usually best for long-term low maintenance. If you are retrofitting an existing home with finished walls, wireless (specifically modern systems like Ajax) is the superior choice to avoid mess and damage.
1. The Case for Wired Alarms (The "Old Faithful")

For decades, wired systems have been the gold standard. Brands like Paradox have built their reputation on hard-wired reliability. In a wired setup, every motion sensor, door contact, and siren is physically connected to the main control panel via cabling.
Why we love them:

items: Zero Interference: A physical wire doesn't care about radio frequency interference (RFI) or thick concrete walls‚Äîa common feature in older homes in Durbanville.
Low Maintenance: You don't need to change batteries in the sensors. The only battery you worry about is the backup battery in the main panel.
Cost: The hardware itself (sensors and keypads) is generally cheaper than wireless equivalents.

content.text: The Downside: The installation is labour-intensive. Running cables through ceilings, chasing walls, or installing conduit (PVC piping) can be messy. If you have a double-storey home with a concrete slab, getting wires to the ground floor is a massive challenge.
Pro Tip: If you are in the "plans phase" of building a house, always tube for a wired alarm. It increases the resale value of the property and allows for a cleaner installation later.

content.alt: Technician connecting wired Paradox alarm system panel in Cape Town.

content.text: 2. The Wireless Revolution (Enter Ajax)

Ten years ago, we would have hesitated to recommend wireless systems for high-risk areas. They were prone to "jamming" and false alarms. However, technology has changed dramatically. Modern systems, particularly the Ajax range, have revolutionized the market.
Why we love them:

items: Aesthetics: There is no trunking, no drilling into your skirting boards, and no dust. It is the cleanest installation possible.
Speed: We can install a full home system in Table View in a matter of hours, not days.
Smart Features: Modern wireless systems are "smart" by default. They integrate seamlessly with your phone, allowing you to arm/disarm and view system health from an app.

content.text: The Downside:

items: Batteries: You will need to replace batteries in the sensors every 3‚Äì5 years.
Signal Issues (Rare): While modern encrypted signals are hard to jam, massive properties with thick reinforced concrete may require range extenders (repeaters).

content.alt: Ajax wireless alarm system with smartphone app control for smart home security.

content.text: 3. The "Cape Town Factor": Environmental Considerations
When choosing your system, you must consider our local environment.

items: Coastal Corrosion: If you live in areas like Camps Bay or Melkbosstrand, sea air eats electronics. Wired connections can corrode if not properly sealed. However, wireless sensors are often better sealed units, though the battery contacts still need checking.

Load Shedding: Both systems rely on a main backup battery. However, in a wired system, the panel powers everything. If the main battery dies, the whole system dies. In a wireless system, the sensors have their own power. If the hub's power fails, the sensors are still alive, and once the hub power is restored (or backed up by a UPS), the system re-syncs immediately.

content.text: 4. Comparing the Costs
Many clients ask us which is cheaper.

items: Wired: Cheaper hardware, but much higher labour costs due to the time required to run cables.
Wireless: More expensive hardware, but significantly lower labour costs.

content.text: In our experience, the final invoice often balances out to be quite similar. The decision should rarely be about price alone, but rather about the application.

Do you need to secure a standalone garage or a granny flat on your property? A wireless system is perfect for this, bridging the gap without digging trenches for cables. Check out our Alarm System Installation page for more details on the specific hardware we use.
5. The Hybrid Approach

You don't always have to choose just one. Many Paradox systems allow for "Hybrid" installations. We can use existing wiring for the sensors that are easy to reach, and add a wireless receiver to reach that new extension or the difficult-to-wire master bedroom. This is often the best route for renovations in older suburbs like Kenilworth.
Conclusion & Pitch
The Verdict:

items: Choose Wired (Paradox) if you are building from scratch, renovating heavily, or want a "fit and forget" system with no sensor batteries.
Choose Wireless (Ajax) if you have a finished home, rent your property, or want the latest in smart-home app technology.

content.text: At Global Security Solutions, we are certified installers for both. We don't push one brand because it's "easier"‚Äîwe install what is right for your home architecture and lifestyle. We have installed hundreds of these systems across the Western Cape, ensuring families sleep soundly regardless of the technology they choose.

title: 5 Reasons Your Alarm Is Going Off in Cape Town (And How to Fix It) üö®
excerpt: Is your alarm going off for no reason? Discover top false alarm causes in Cape Town‚Äîfrom old sensors to low batteries. Fix it today! üõ°Ô∏è
author: Global Security Team

content.text: The Pain: It‚Äôs 3:00 AM. You are fast asleep, and suddenly, your siren starts screaming. Your heart races, you grab your panic button, and check your cameras... nothing. No intruder. Just silence and a very loud siren.

The Agitation: False alarms are more than just a nuisance that angers your neighbors. They are dangerous. If your system cries "wolf" too often, you‚Äîand your armed response company‚Äîmight stop treating the activations seriously. That hesitation could cost you dearly when a real threat arrives.
In this article, we draw on our years of experience servicing the Western Cape to explain exactly why this happens.

Generally, false alarms in Cape Town are caused by aging backup batteries (worsened by frequent power cuts), dirty or insect-infested sensors, strong drafts from open windows, or corroded wiring due to coastal air. Below, we break down how to troubleshoot and solve these issues.
1. The "Load Shedding" Hangover: Low Batteries
In our experience servicing homes across Durbanville and the Northern Suburbs, the number one cause of false alarms is the backup battery.

When the power cuts, your system relies entirely on the battery. If that battery is old or struggling to hold a charge, the voltage drops. This voltage fluctuation sends "confused" signals to the alarm panel, often triggering a siren activation.

Pro Tip: If your keypad shows a "Trouble" light or a "Low Battery" indicator, don't ignore it. A standard lead-acid battery usually lasts 2‚Äì3 years, but with constant Stage 4 or 6 load shedding, we often see them fail in under 18 months.

content.alt: Technician testing a faulty 12V 7Ah alarm backup battery with a multimeter showing low voltage caused by frequent Cape Town load shedding, requiring immediate replacement.

content.text: If you are struggling with power issues, check out our Load Shedding Security Solutions page for battery backups and solar options.
2. The "Cape Doctor" & Open Windows
Cape Town is famous for its wind. If you live in windy areas like Blouberg or Milnerton, a simple draft can trigger a false alarm.

Passive Infrared (PIR) sensors detect rapid changes in heat energy. A sudden gust of wind through an open window can move curtains or plants, creating a "movement" signature that the sensor interprets as a person. Even a sudden change in temperature from a hot draft can trip older, less sensitive units.
The Fix: Ensure all windows are shut before arming your alarm.
The Upgrade: If you need to leave windows open for ventilation, consider installing "Pet Friendly" or Dual-Tech sensors which are more forgiving of environmental noise.
3. Creepy Crawlies: Spiders and Geckos
We often find that sensors installed in corners become warm, cozy homes for spiders and geckos, especially in Somerset West and leafier suburbs.
If a gecko crawls directly across the lens of your PIR sensor, it looks like a massive object to the detector. This is a classic cause of the "3 AM mystery alarm."

content.alt: Internal view of a dirty PIR motion sensor circuit board covered in spider webs and dust, which is a common cause of false alarms in residential security systems.

content.text: Maintenance Tip: gently vacuum around your sensors once a month to keep webs away. If the problem persists, we can seal the cable entry points with silicone to prevent insects from entering the unit.
4. Aging Equipment and Corrosion
Living near the coast in areas like Camps Bay or Clifton presents a unique challenge: sea air. The salt content in the air corrodes copper wiring and sensor contacts over time.
Corroded wires increase resistance, leading to intermittent signal drops that the alarm panel interprets as a "tamper" or an "open zone."
If your system is more than 7‚Äì10 years old, the plastic lenses on the sensors may also have degraded, making them hypersensitive to sunlight and car headlights.
Solution: Visit our Repairs & Upgrades page. Sometimes, replacing the old cabling or swapping out 10-year-old sensors for modern digital ones is the only permanent fix.
5. Loose Cabling or Faulty Contacts
Have you recently had renovations done? Or perhaps a door slammed shut a little too hard?

Magnetic contacts (the small white blocks on your doors and windows) can shift over time. If the magnet moves just a few millimeters too far from the reed switch, the system might think the door is "floating" open. On a windy night, the door rattling in the frame is enough to break that weak magnetic connection and trigger the alarm.
Safety Note: Never just "Bypass" a faulty zone and forget about it. That leaves a hole in your security perimeter that criminals will eventually find.
Conclusion & Pitch

To summarize, if your alarm is going off without an intruder, it is likely a cry for help from your hardware. Whether it's a battery killed by load shedding, a spider in the sensor, or corrosion from the Cape Town air, these issues don't fix themselves.

title: Why Is My Electric Fence Making a Clicking Noise?
excerpt: Is your electric fence making a loud clicking noise? It could be a sign of arcing or vegetation damage. Learn how to fix it and when to call Global Security Solutions.
author: Global Security Team

content.text: If you are a homeowner in Durbanville or the Northern Suburbs, you know the sound. It‚Äôs a quiet night, and suddenly you hear a loud, rhythmic click-click-click coming from your perimeter wall.
It is annoying, but it is also a warning sign.

A silent fence is a happy fence. If your system is clicking loudly, it usually means power is leaking somewhere along the line. This is often caused by "arcing," which is a spark jumping from the live wire to something it shouldn't touch.
Here is what causes it and why you need Electric Fence Repairs before it becomes a security risk.
1. Vegetation on the Line (The #1 Culprit)
In the Western Cape, things grow fast‚Äîespecially after the winter rains.
If a branch, vine, or bush touches a live wire, the electricity will arc (jump) to the plant to find a path to the ground.

The Sound: A sharp, snapping click.
The Fix: Trim back all bushes at least 10cm away from your electric fence lines.
2. Cracked or Broken Insulators (Bobbins)
The plastic "bobbins" that hold the wire are exposed to the harsh Cape Town sun and UV rays every day. Over time, plastic becomes brittle and cracks.
The Problem: When an insulator cracks, the electricity jumps through the crack to the metal bracket.
The Weather Factor: You will notice this more on misty mornings in areas like Melkbosstrand or Table View, as moisture conducts electricity better.
3. Loose Wires in the Wind

The "South Easter" wind can wreak havoc on older fences. If your tensioners are old, the wires can sag. When the wind blows, the slack wires might touch each other or the wall, creating a short circuit.
Why You Should Not Ignore the Noise
Ignoring the click isn't just about the noise pollution.

items: False Alarms: Eventually, the voltage drop will trigger your alarm, likely at 3 AM.
Reduced Voltage: If the power is leaking, the shock is weaker. An intruder might be able to climb over without getting a proper shock.
Battery Drain: Your energizer has to work harder, which kills your backup battery faster. (See our guide on Load Shedding Security Solutions).

Electrical fencing is dangerous. If you cannot see an obvious branch on the line, do not try to fix the wiring yourself.

title: The Ultimate Load Shedding Security Guide 2026
excerpt: Is your alarm beeping when the power goes out? Discover the essential upgrades needed to keep your Cape Town home secure during Stage 6 load shedding.
author: Kyle Cass

content.text: Load shedding has become a daily reality in Cape Town, but it shouldn't compromise your safety. We've seen a sharp rise in opportunistic crimes occurring exactly when streetlights and house alarms go dark. This guide covers the essential upgrades you need to stay secure.
1. The Weakest Link: Your Alarm Battery

Most older alarm systems run on Lead-Acid batteries designed for occasional outages, not daily cycling. If your keypad beeps or goes dead during a 4-hour slot, your battery is likely sulphated and useless.

items: Solution: Upgrade to Lithium-Iron (LiFePO4) batteries.
Benefit: They last 4x longer and charge faster.
Cost: Slightly higher upfront, but they save money on replacements.

content.text: 2. Electric Fence Energizers

Your electric fence is your first line of defense. If the energizer battery dies, the fence is just decorative wire. We recommend installing a dedicated battery backup unit specifically for your energizer to ensure it holds a 10kV charge throughout the night.
3. Solar CCTV Cameras

Blind spots are dangerous. Traditional CCTV systems shut down without power. We are now installing independent solar-powered cameras from Hikvision and Ezviz that run completely off-grid. They connect to your phone via 4G, so even if your home Wi-Fi dies, you still get alerts.
4. Gate Motors are Critical

Being stuck outside your gate is a major hijacking risk. Ensure your Centurion gate motor has high-capacity backup batteries. We also install anti-theft cages, as battery theft increases during load shedding.

title: Top 5 Security Tips for Cape Town Residents
excerpt: Crime trends in Cape Town are changing. Here are the top 5 things you can do today to secure your home, from lighting to perimeter beams.

content.text: Living in Cape Town requires a proactive approach to security. It's not just about having an alarm; it's about layering your defenses to deter criminals before they even reach your door.
1. Light Up Your Perimeter
Criminals hate light. Installing motion-sensor floodlights around your property is one of the most cost-effective deterrents available. Ensure there are no dark corners for intruders to hide in.
2. Test Your Battery Backup
With frequent load shedding, your alarm battery takes a beating. If it's older than 18 months, it likely won't last through a 4-hour outage. Test it regularly or upgrade to Lithium-Ion.
3. Cut Back Vegetation
Overgrown bushes near your electric fence or driveway provide perfect cover for ambush. Keep your garden neat and ensure your perimeter fence is free of foliage that causes false alarms.
4. Be Visible
Make sure your alarm company board is visible and your house number is clear. In an emergency, every second counts for the response vehicle to find you.
5. Get to Know Your Neighbors
A strong neighborhood watch is better than any tech. Join your local WhatsApp group and look out for each other.

title: Understanding Regulations for Electric Fencing in South Africa
excerpt: Did you know that non-compliant electric fencing can void your insurance? Learn about the COC requirements and safety laws.
author: Rashaad Steyn

content.text: Electric fencing is a popular deterrent in South Africa, but it strictly regulated by the Department of Labour. Installing a non-compliant fence is not only illegal but can leave you liable for injuries.
What is a COC?

A Certificate of Compliance (COC) acts as a guarantee that your electric fence installation complies with the Occupational Health and Safety Act. Without this document, your insurance company may reject a burglary claim.
Key Legal Requirements

items: Fences must be marked with yellow warning signs every 10 meters.
The fence must not be electrified within 1.5m of the ground unless it's behind a physical barrier.
Energizers must be installed in a safe, accessible location.
Earth spikes must be installed at specific intervals.

content.text: At Global Security Solutions, we issue a COC with every new installation, ensuring you are fully covered.

title: Alert: Latest Crime Trends in Cape Town & Prevention Strategies
excerpt: From remote jamming to roof access, criminals are evolving. Here is what our tactical teams are seeing on the ground and how to counter it.
author: Kyle Cass

content.text: As security technology improves, so do the methods used by criminals. We have noticed a distinct shift in tactics used by syndicates in the greater Cape Town area over the last 6 months.
1. Roof Access Burglaries

Criminals are bypassing perimeter beams by lifting roof tiles. Standard internal PIRs often don't catch them until they are already inside. We recommend installing ceiling-void sensors to detect movement in your roof space.
2. Gate Motor Theft

With load shedding, backup batteries are high-value targets. Thieves break open gate motors to steal the battery or the entire motor. An anti-theft bracket is now a mandatory requirement for insurance in many areas.
3. Remote Jamming
Always physically check your car door is locked. Jammers prevent the locking signal from reaching your car. We also recommend upgrading to anti-jamming remotes for your alarm and gate.
Stay Ahead
The best defense is a layered one. Don't rely on a single system. Contact us to update your threat assessment.
